docs.snippet: Critics said the warning could herald a new effort to suppress free speech by authoritarian governments emboldened by the U.S. president’s words.

headline.print_headline: Cambodia Cites Trump’s Example in Warning Foreign Media to ‘Respect the State’
headline.main: Cambodian Government Cites Trump in Threatening Foreign News Outlets

docs.snippet: Will the March for Science help or hurt scientists and scientific evidence?

docs.snippet: Some recent works by local artists are more overtly political than others, but many suggest a sense of helplessness toward what is widely seen as Beijing’s tightening grip.

headline.print_headline: Politics Infuses the Arts in a Dejected Hong Kong
headline.main: As Hong Kong Ponders Its Future Under Beijing, Politics Infuses Its Art

docs.snippet: After complaints from brands whose content was shown alongside offensive material online, the search giant pledged to improve its safeguards.

headline.print_headline: Google to Help Advertisers Keep Away From Hate Speech
headline.main: Google Tries to Stop Ads From Appearing Next to Hate Speech

docs.snippet: A conference room on the third floor of The New York Times building has been repurposed as a small museum.

docs.snippet: The city’s Campaign Finance Board is holding a competition to design a new sticker to be handed out during the Nov. 7 elections, when voters will cast ballots for mayor.

headline.print_headline: Unifying a Cacophonous City With Civics. Well, Stickers.

docs.snippet: Almost two dozen civil rights activists were demanding that Mr. Sessions, the Alabama senator, refuse Donald J. Trump’s nomination as attorney general.

docs.snippet: Companies have difficulty controlling where their ads appear because of the largely automated nature of online advertising.

headline.main: Brands Try to Blacklist Breitbart, but Ads Slip Through Anyway

docs.snippet: Meet Iain Armitage, who rose to fame with a YouTube channel where he offers reviews of “Othello” and “Cats.”

docs.snippet: Corporations have crisis management firms at their behest. Small-business owners have to rely on their own wits to respond to political animosity.
